intro: Chondrodendron toxicoferum, commonly known as the "poison ivy of the Andes," is a climbing plant native to South America. It belongs to the family Euphorbiaceae and is characterized by its compound leaves and distinctive, reddish-brown stems. The plant contains toxic compounds, primarily phorbol esters, which can cause severe skin irritation in humans. It thrives in tropical and subtropical regions, often found in humid, shaded environments. Due to its toxic properties, it is generally avoided by both humans and animals.
